共享單車全球大熱，用電話嘟一嘟專屬單車，便即刻解鎖任踩任泊，並毋須還車，吸引大批用家踩單車代步。豈料此服務殺入香港不足2日，便遭遇挫折！

目前沙田已進駐幾百架鮮艷奪目的共享單車。《港呢啲》前往試玩，豈料許多單車落地第2天，已東歪西倒。斷威吔線又有、爛車尾燈又有，許多單車手把軟膠更疑被盜去，剩下光禿禿的鐵架。

共享單車在內地屢遭盜竊，有公司甚至虧損倒閉。而香港的單車老鼠似乎已整裝待發。

「我覺得(共享單車)喺香港唔work㗎，香港人始終唔自律。文明就要自律，唔自律點文明呢，係咪先？」單車愛好者石同學看見簇新的共享單車極速變殘，不勝唏噓，「擺喺度都畀人偷手把，人哋下一個如果想用，咁咪冇得用囉！」

記者租用一輛單車試踩，半小時收費5港元。單車坐墊夠厚，在單車徑來回兜圈，上斜落斜，問題不大。沒料到踩了10分鐘不夠，即發生驚險一幕：右腳踏毫無先兆地整個飛脫，幸而當時車速慢才避過一劫。如果車上的是初學者或小朋友，隨時發生意外。

事實上，共享單車甫推出已在網絡劣評如潮，用家紛紛表示：「乜都冇講就扣50蚊？冇嘢呀？」「信用卡資料畀晒你？好得人驚喎！」記者發現，GoBee.Bike提出的單車按金收費一時一樣，明明在官網中列明收399港元，其後又在facebook回應指測試期間僅收1蚊，及後又說推廣優惠期間是50港元......

Inspired by booming development of bicycle-sharing businesses in the Chinese mainland, Raphael Cohen, chief executive and co-founder of Gobee.bike, launched the first bicycle-sharing system in Hong Kong on Wednesday.

Cohen took just two months to go from an idea to a startup-company reality. He said he travels to the Chinese mainland frequently and a couple of months ago: “I was visiting the mainland and saw the bicycles at streets. And I thought there is something to do and I would like to bring and develop the concept in Hong Kong and the rest of the world.”

Cohen saw very high growth potential for the bicycle-sharing business which has challenged certain markets. Cohen saw high potential in Hong Kong despite public areas available for cycling being limited.

Compared with the business model of mainland bicycle-sharing companies such as OfO and Mobike, Cohen pointed out that Gobee.bike was similar but they will focus on more mature markets like Hong Kong where facilities are better built.


Hong Kong’s first bicycle-sharing system launched with over 1,000 smart bikes painted bright green spread out across key locations in the New Territories including bike-friendly districts like Sha Tin, Tai Po and Ma On Shan.

Cohen expected the number of bikes to reach 20,000 by July this year and Gobee.bike aims to cover most areas in Hong Kong – including Kowloon, Hong Kong Island, Discovery Bay and Park Island – by the end of this year.

Cohen said customers needed to pay a deposit of HK$399 (US$51.31) and sign a contract first through the brand’s mobile application which is currently only available on Android phones; the IOS version is expected to be launched soon. A customer would locate the nearest bicycle through an interactive map. Cyclists need to unlock the bright green bikes they find on the street by scanning a unique QR code. They can park the bike at any designated public area. Gobee.bike’s colleagues will handle management of the bikes.

Gobee.bike charges customers HK$5 per half hour and payments can be made directly through the mobile application by linking a credit card, the company says.

Cohen said the company has already finished the C seed round of investment and the round was led by Swiss Founders Fund, Cocoon Ignite Ventures, Lastminute.com group’s founder and chairman Fabio Cannavale, Lamivoie Capital and Goldman Sachs alumni as well as individual investors.

Cohen said he had two other partners for this business and they had already established a team of 15 colleagues.


It’s not the first company Cohen has started. Prior to Gobee.bike, Cohen was the co-founder of HotelQuickly and Foodpanda.com. “I have been in various vertical startup businesses. I like to run new things which could be different things but by using similar knowledge like on management and operations,” said Cohen.

The company aims to extend its reach on a global scale over the next two to three months after the launching in Hong Kong.
